newsitem.title: UK: Sleepy drivers worse than drunks - study.
newsitem.headline: Sleepy drivers worse than drunks - study.

text.p: Sleepy drivers may be more dangerous than drunk drivers, Australian researchers reported on Wednesday.
They said tests on sleep-deprived volunteers showed that staying up for just over a day could hurt performance just as much as a few drinks.
"Moderate levels of fatigue produce higher levels of impairment than the proscribed level of alcohol intoxication," they wrote in a letter to the science journal Nature.
Drew Dawson of the University of South Australia's Centre for Sleep Research and Kathryn Reid of the University of Adelaide tested 40 people in two experiments.

"In one they were kept awake for 28 hours (from 8:00 until 12:00 the following day) and in the other they were asked to consume 10 to 15 grams of alcohol at 30 minute intervals from 8:00 until their mean blood alcohol concentration reached 0.10 percent," they wrote.
They used a computer test of hand-eye coordination in both experiments. "Performance decreased significantly in both conditions," they wrote.
"After 17 hours of sustained wakefulness...performance decreased to a level equivalent to the performance impairment observed at a blood alcohol concentration of 0.05 percent," they found.
"This is the proscribed level of alcohol intoxication in many Western industrialised countries."
Being kept up for 24 hours made people react as badly as when their blood alcohol levels were 0.1 percent, Dawson and Reid found.
"It is clear that the effects of moderate sleep loss on performance are similar to moderate alcohol intoxication," they concluded.

"As about 50 percent of shift-workers do not sleep on the day before the first night-shift, and levels of fatigue on subsequent night-shifts can be even higher, our data indicate that the performance impairment associated with shift-work could be even greater than reported here."
